by the pulse height weighting technique (PHWT).

For the energy resolution of the neutron beam, for the
Doppler broadening of cross-section line shapes, for
Two C6-D6 liquid scintillator cells as gamma
detectors placed perpendicular to neutron beam at a
distance of about 3 cm from beam axis and 9.2 cm
backward from the sample position. Directly coupled
to EMI-9823QKB photomultiplier tubes. The light output
of the detectors was calibrated at 662, 1173, 1332 keV
by means of 137Cs and 60Co reference sources. An
additional calibration point at 6.13 MeV was obtained
by means of a composite 238Pu/13C source.
chamber from PTB Braunschweig - for neutron flux
measurement as well as Li-6 neutron flux monitors.

Spallation reaction of fast protons on the
massive lead target moderated in a surrounding
5.8 cm thick water cooling layer surrounding the lead
Neutron flux 10**5 neutrons/cm2/pulse at the sample
position). Resolution in neutron energy is better than
0.1% in the range of the present measurement, i.e.
below 8 keV. Nearly symmetrical Gaussian-shaped beam
The neutron flux was determined relative to the
235U(n,f) cross section by means of calibrated fission
chamber from PTB Braunschweig. During the measurement
the flux was checked online by a low-mass 6Li neutron
Flight path 187.5 m from spallation target to
Prompt gamma-ray cascade following neutron capture.
Zr-O2 oxide powder pressed to pellet of 22 mm diameter,
thickness 3.5mm, mass 4.46 g, encapsulated twice in
inner Al and a welded outer Ti container, both with
0.2 mm thick walls. 93Zr activity was 62.6 MBq.
Traces of Mo and S were also present in the sample -
below 0.01 %, the contribution of these impurities to
the measured capture yield was not negligible.
Au and Pb samples of the same diameter were used for
repeated neutron flux measurements and background runs.
The capture yield has been investigated by means of an
R-matrix analysis, using SAMMY code in the Reich-Moore
data analysis procedure are lower than 2%.
Uncertainty due to the energy dependence of the
neutron flux and to the fraction of the neutron beam
covered by the sample; determined by applying the
saturated resonance technique, using 0.1 mm thick Au
sample, to the saturated resonance at 4.9 eV in 197Au.
